We focused on extending a graph query language, such as SPARQL [13], Cypher [35] or GraphQL [18], with connecting tree patterns (CTPs) that they currently do not support (our requirement (R1) from Section 1).
We now compare the winner of the above comparisons, namely MoLESP, with QGSTP [39] on the 18M edges DBPedia dataset and 312 CTPs used in their evaluation.

We now introduce an algorithmic variant called Merge-oriented ESP, or MoESP, which finds many (but not all) CTP results for arbitrary numbers of seed sets.

They share a set of global variables whose names start with an uppercase letter: Res, PrioQ, Hist (the search history), and TreesRootedIn (to store the trees by their roots); the latter is needed to find Merge candidates fast.

In this work, we formally show how to integrate connecting tree patterns (CTPs, in short) within a graph query language such as SPARQL or Cypher, leading to an Extended Query Language (or EQL, in short).
QGSTP [39] and LANCET [40] are the most recent GSTP approximation algorithms, for specific cost functions based on node and edge (LANCET) weights.

Our graphs are stored in a simple table graph(id,source, edgeLabel, target) within PostgreSQL 12.4; unless otherwise specified, we delegate to Postgres the BGP evaluation, and joining their results with CTP ones (Section 3).
To cope with very large search spaces, we propose an efficient pruning technique and formally establish a large set of cases where our algorithm, MoLESP, is complete even with pruning.

(1) We formally define an Extended Query Language (EQL, in short), which combines together Basic Graph Pattern (or conjunctive) queries at the core of both SPARQL and Cypher, and Connecting Tree Patterns (CTPs, in short).

mergeAll implements aggressive merging; by calling processTree on each new Merge result, through recordForMerging, the result is available in the future iterations of mergeAll, thus ensuring all the desired Merge.

This shows that the extra cost incurred by LESP and MoLESP, which limit or compensate for edgeset pruning (by injecting more trees), is worth paying for the completeness guarantees of MoLESP.

(4) We experimentally show that: (𝑖) baseline algorithms inspired from breadth-first search are unfeasible even for small graphs; (𝑖𝑖) the optimizations we bring here over the GAM algorithm [6] strongly reduce the search time; (𝑖𝑖𝑖) integrating our MoLESP algorithm with a simple conjunctive graph query engine allows to efficiently evaluate queries in our extended language (Section 5).
